segments.text: Beer cost, but most of the hard liquor was $4.
Well, it was $3 to $4.
The better brands, Sheva's Ribbon was $4.
And that was for, you know, the big bottle.
And I'm not sure which it was in the fifth or fourth quart, but even then that was a good price.
And he hung around the officer's club.
Nobody had a, we didn't really have living rooms.
The men, the male officers, I think all of those who just had those living areas had patios or something attached.
The men had built and made some sort of a recreation area.
The women didn't, at least not where I was.
Something else that needs to be said.
What I'm saying, what I'm telling are my experiences and the way it was at my hospital.
The hospitals were not standard.
They were laid out differently.
The hospital areas were, living situations were different wherever you went.
We felt pretty lucky to have women, felt pretty lucky to have individual rooms and indoor vitrines.
We had a hairdresser in the back of our officer's club.
And really, you know, this was on Longman Post, which was very large, and there was just all kinds of things there.
There were two hospitals.
There were all sorts of headquarters.
There were a lot of
Well, there was a WAC detachment not very far from us.
There were a lot of civilian women there, Department of the Army civilians.
And so, you know, there was a real need for women's facilities.
And it was a Vietnamese man, obviously French-trained,
If we had any length to our hair at all, he had us looking like Marie Antoinette, lots of big curls, this upswept kind of thing.
So we had our hair done.
I was a manicurist.
I had nails for the first time in my life.
She did pedicures.
off of that, you know, when things were slow on the ward and took off my combat boots and had my toenails done in addition to the rest of them.
But that isn't, you know, what it was like every place.
Not every place had a, you know, a rare team attached.
So treating many, you know, respiratory patients was difficult in many places.
We had nice big hospital beds throughout most of the hospital.
And it wasn't true when I got there, but we eventually got them.
And they didn't have running water on the wards when I got there, but they were in the process of putting it in.
So we had hot and cold running water very soon.
And had showers on them.
on the wards for the patients.
We soon had air conditioning.
I heard tales about how miserable it was before air conditioning, especially for the guys in full body casts or half body casts.
So they had gone for some time without that.
The women's quarters were eventually updated.
Everybody got a ceiling and the whole, you know, each hooch was air-conditioned, central air-conditioned.
So things were different.
It just depended on where you were and when you were.
And were you involved with the MedCap program?
I never went out.
I knew about him.
I was afraid to put myself in danger.
And it wasn't just that I physically was afraid.
I don't remember shaking my boots thinking about it.
But my parents were...
I didn't... Well, I knew they would not take something happening to me very well.
And my brother at the time was 1A.
Now he eventually got that changed, but he was flunking out of school and lost his deferment.
And then the other thing was I lost a boyfriend over there just before I went.
So I was very much aware of what a family went through.
I went from his wake, from the funeral home, to the airplane in St. Louis that would take me out to the West Coast.
report call was such that I had to leave.
I couldn't stay until the next day.
So I didn't go to his funeral.
But I was afraid to get out, you know, in the countryside.
I didn't like the idea, I told you, of flying up anywhere by chopper or going over land.
I knew it was dangerous.
Did many civilians come to the base?
They had a lot of Vietnamese workers.
Everybody worked in our laundry, in our kitchen.
There were a few people who worked on the wards.
There was a translator or two, probably more.
There were stretcher bearers assigned to the emergency room.
That was just our hospital.
Over the whole post.

One of the first things I remember about being in country, got in there at nighttime, but I think it was when I was bused from the replacement center, which was at Benoit, which was just adjacent to Long Bend Post.
From there over to the hospital.
I remember turning a corner and
noticing these people stooped over working on the ditches and pouring concrete and all this stuff.
And then looking again and realizing it was women.
There weren't any men to do that work.
It was women.
They were down to women.
What were your feelings about the Vietnamese people?
They changed over time.
I'm always unsettled when I can't speak to somebody and we used a few words over and over and over to get things across.
It was frustrating trying to work with them because they didn't understand.
Now what
And later on, as my tour continued and ended, I found myself thinking of them and even calling them goofs.
And I felt bad at the time.
I felt worse later.
I think it was... You know, it's hard to translate at the time and remember what's going on and what has gone on in their lives, or even to know, really, what they've been through.

So many of them, so often when we took patients on recovery, on pre-op rather, when they came in, when one of the Vietnamese came in as a casualty, they often came in with two or three family members.
And they were a bother.
We had to remember to order meal trays for them, which they didn't like.
We didn't usually have meal trays on the pre-op recovery.
They, you know, they were in the way.
They struck you as not being very bright.
That wasn't it at all.
They couldn't understand you.
They were numbed by what had gone on.
They were there with their family member because maybe they wouldn't see him again.
There wasn't much attempt.
I mean, we picked up Vietnamese casualties, civilian casualties, as we could.
I don't know how often or how much of the time they went out of their way to bring in civilian casualties, but we got a good number of them.
But you always had the time element and the communication factor.
And patients, we often did the emergency surgery for them.
And then the next day or the day after, they would be sent to a provincial hospital over in Benoit.
And then you just wondered where they ever did end up.
And if those people being picked up 30 miles away
and brought into Long Bend, had any idea where Long Bend was or if they were ever told.
So they had to come along.
And then they were, you know, certainly further, I think, abused just by the whole system.
Big people, I mean, we are big compared to those people.
And, you know, we...
maybe and maybe not looked kindly at them.
Later on, when I was on a different ward, a medical ward, we still had Vietnamese patients there.
We got closer to them.
There was more of a rapport.
I remember thinking of them more as people than I did the ones we took care of on pre-op and recovery.
There was a lot of shuffling of people.
But when we had them for a length of time,
And under circumstances that were a lot more normal, we weren't dealing with smashed people.
But on the medical ward, I certainly found it easier to feel more humanely toward them.
We had a little girl, four or five, who had a tracheostomy that had been put in by a French doctor.
Her grandmother did speak French, and she was with her.
cute little thing.
It really was a doll, just easy to love, love back.
This thing had been done, oh, the wrong kind of a tube had been put in.
It was a closed-in tube.
And she, you know, usually, she couldn't get rid of the mucus in her lungs very easily, and she developed pneumonia, and that's when we got her.
And there was an attempt made to
to revise that to see what was wrong with her, why she needed the tracheostomy.
We couldn't get a real good story.
And it turned out there was some sort of a tumor, a benign kind of tumor, but it would continue to grow and occlude her airway.
And she would always have to have the tracheostomy.
So there was that attempt to...
not just take care of her, but do something better for her.
And for a while, she needed an oxygen tent, and we didn't have such a thing.
And so the corpsman rigged one up, and it was the most gosh-awful looking thing you've ever seen.
They had her in a big baby bed, kind of a bed, and had rigged
There was clear plastic.
They had clear plastic all around her.
But to get the steam, they had just this series of stuff, you know, bottles and tubes and all this.
And it made a lot of noise.
But it worked.
And, you know, the guys were tickled to do that and to be around her.
And they liked her mama's song, too.
Grandma was very pleasant company.
And there were others.
you know, that made a mark on us.
And that I hope we made a mark on more so than places where we put people to die, you know, back in the corner and left them, you know.
And how did your peers act towards the Vietnamese?
There were some who...
you know, who were really fine toward them, and others who weren't.
I came away, well, I went thinking I wasn't prejudiced.
I had not grown up around any ethnic minority, and had encountered blacks in St. Louis when I was in school.
And it was nothing but a positive experience.
I wasn't buddy-buddy friends with any black person.
But later on, I think I understood how easily you can become prejudiced and biased, and that you can read things into a person's behavior, certainly read it wrong,
and judge them very badly.
You really do need to know why they have this dull, dumb look on their faces.
There's a real reason.
If I'd gone through the kind of trauma they'd gone through, I'd have a dull look, too.
Probably chronically depressed.
These are people who have grown up for generations.
in warfare, just trying to eke out a living and stay alive no matter how.
And there was not a lot of high-minded niceness in them.
Or it, you know, it hadn't been there for a while, or they didn't have many opportunities for it to show.
And did you take any kind of precautions against BC, or was it not a big threat?
It was not a big threat on Long Bend.
On the hospital grounds, all the buildings were bunkered outside with barrels that were filled with something, dirt or rocks or something.
And then on top of the barrels would be two or three layers of
sandbags.
There had been some true bunkers dug into the ground and then bunkered over areas like tornado shelters.
But they were out back behind, you'd have to walk a distance to get to them.
It's like being in a tornado.
You want to get yourself down and flat and out of the open area as soon as possible.
So to go from a building to a bunker, you could be hurt on the way.
So they felt it was best to...
and just bunker the buildings.
And what we were to do in the case of alerts, we were to get down on the ground.
In our rooms, we were to get under the beds, put our steel pots on, get under the beds.
And on the wards, we were to get our patients on the floor and then put their mattress on top of them.
And they'd have the steel frame of the bed over that.
We had some incoming shells we were fired on a few times, and I was really only aware of it one time.
I slept through a lot.
And then I think our particular compound, this place was so big, the whole post wouldn't be hit at the same time.
And I didn't know it until much later, but our hospital was fairly close to the ammo dump, a big ammo dump that served probably a huge area.
And there were twin towers, radio towers or something, not far away.
And the story was that the BC used those towers to sight in on the ammo dump.
which wasn't that far from us.
So I think we're in more potential danger than a lot of us realized.
And then I found out later, after I left, sometime in the next six months, some of our buildings were hit and damaged.
The one time that I was aware that I'd gone to bed fairly early, it was a time when things were going on in our...
Officer's Club had been told to close down early.
And I'd had plenty to drink.
I was... Well, I was still awake and functioning because I went home.
I showered and rolled up my hair before going to bed.
And then I was awakened around midnight, and the gal trying to wake me up had a hard time, and my door was locked.
She couldn't come in and get me.
So I finally did get up,
And I was groggy.
I kind of knew what was going on, but not really.
And I put my steel pot on, and it wouldn't fit over my hair rollers.
That worried me a little bit.
I laid down in the corner.
I couldn't get under my bed, either, with all this on my hair.
I didn't have the presence of mind to take my rollers out.
So I just got down in the corner on the floor, in the corner formed by my bed, and I had a refrigerator.
And I sort of set the helmet over my head.
And then I did worry because I worried, but I didn't do anything about it.
I had a big oscillating fan.
on top of the refrigerator.
It was one of those things with a big wide open spring.
Big enough you could just put your whole hand into it.
And I did think, I hope nothing hits too close to us because if it does it will knock that fan down on top of me and chew me up.
But I didn't do anything.
The next morning I had to work and I had a headache.
I didn't often drink to the point I had a hangover.
That was unusual for me.
But I had a hangover that day, and I felt bad, and my head hurt.
And I went to work, and the ward was a mess.
It was just an absolute mess, because they had all gone on red alert also, and the patients were on the floor.
And usually, everyone wakes up around 5.
They turn the lights on on the ward at 5 and start taking temperatures and vital signs and making guys get up and shower and make their beds and all this stuff.
But I guess the night had been so crazy that no one was waking up on time.
And so they were just getting up, and there was a little nest under the nurse's station desk where the nurse had fallen asleep.
And things were just messy, and they were trying to be organized and so on.
And a fellow came in on the ward, came onto the ward that I knew.
He was a guy I had known in El Paso before I'd been
Station in Vietnam.
And I'd seen him a few times.
He was over there with a team that was testing a new, field testing a new weapon.
It was a Vulcan.
It's called a Vulcan.
It's a Gatling gun, and it had been mounted on an Army personnel carrier, an APC.
They hadn't been done before, so they were trying it out.
And I had seen some other guys,
from that team just about once.
One of them I had known in El Paso, too.
And Jimmy came over to tell me that one of these guys had been killed that night.
And not very far from the hospital, there was a BOQ, an officer's quarters area, just two or three blocks from our compound.
And that's where they stayed when they came on to post.
And this fellow had stood outside, outside the bunker.
They did have a bunker.
Watching all the, you know, the firefights, the lights and everything going on.
And he was killed by a shell fragment and it just went into his chest and took him immediately.
Just instantly.
And, you know, I felt very bad.
I knew he had a wife and a couple of kids at home.
And young, nice guy.
And do you know my headache left?
The hangover was gone.
I wouldn't have thought, I didn't expect the psychological effects of a hangover to be, you know, to override the physical effects.
Okay.
Were you aware of any relationships among Vietnamese men and American women?
No.
No, that's a mix I didn't hear about.
Okay.
And was racism a problem?
Once in a while you were aware of it.
There were a few of the black enlisted men who wore chains with black clenched fists on them.
We had one fellow, a lot of the wards did this, ours I don't think as much as some others.
But they would hang flags from people's home states.
They had a big expanse of ceiling in these Quonset huts.
And a lot of people would bring their home flag.
And one of our doctors had brought the rebel flag, the Confederate battle flag.
And it was hanging right across from where we had put this fellow in bed.
He was a black fellow.
And he was very upset about that.
And he was kind of loud about being upset.
And, you know, you just had the feeling, uh-oh, troublemaker.
And we moved him to the other ward.
The medical ward was two wards.
And we just moved him around to the other side.
I think we did take the flag down, too.
I don't remember whether we took it down before we moved him or not, but I know that black did go down.
And he was a model patient.
He was fine.
But the fellas, you know, they were aware of it.
Another thing, one of my corpsmen was a black fellow, young.
This kid, I never knew how much I could believe.
He was real charming and personable and would just tell the wildest stories.
And he claimed he was only 17 when he came into Vietnam.
And it was hard, you know, it's hard to tell a young kid that age, you know, when he's 17 to 19.
You might, you know, tell younger, but you can't really tell.
And he told amazing stories about what he had done before he had come to Vietnam.
He'd grown up on the streets in New Jersey, and he was a tough guy.
Or he'd have you believe he was.
And he came to us as a corpsman after having been in the boonies as an infantryman for several months, probably six months.
And he told me...
He just couldn't stand it any longer.

He couldn't stand the killing any longer, and he begged and begged, and occasionally this did happen, that fellows were rotated, you know, people who had no prior medical training were rotated into the hospitals, and they got OJT as corpsmen, as medical corpsmen.
And he told that there was that
There were racial problems out in the field.
And he said that the Vietnamese, that they had a choice of firing on brothers or white guys or a group that had a lot of white guys.
They picked the white guys rather than firing on the brothers.
And seemed to say that there was, you know, an understanding there.
I never heard it from anyone else.
And as I say, this guy, you know, well, you know, he had given me cause to doubt his truthfulness at times.
That was hard because he was, you know, he was a fun, sweet kid.
But, you know, I just don't know.
And was sexism a problem?
Well, yes and no.
uh, sexism as it, uh, there was a lot going on then.
I wasn't aware of the women's movement, was not involved with it or think it.
I needed to be a part of it for a long time because I was just being very selfish.
I was, uh, a woman, uh, uh, army officer.
I was a nurse.
And being in the Army Nurse Corps is a lot different from being in the Women's Army Corps, the WACs.
No wax now.
There's no women's army corps.
But it was special being a woman in the nurse corps.
And we were treated with a great deal of respect and courtesy.
This was all, I think, well much of it was true, much of it was just on the surface.
There was resentment
among male nurses toward female nurses.
At that time, male nurses had not been officers long enough to have gained any superiority in rank.
I knew a couple of majors, and I believe one became a lieutenant colonel when I was there.
A lieutenant colonel was about as high as men were at the time.
So there was hard feelings there.
I think we enjoyed the privileges we had.
For the most part, we really enjoyed them.
The guys were eager to do things for us.
There were a lot who wanted something in return.
One of the things, and I don't think this was done consciously, but when the guys had a chance to be around one of us, they opened up.
They spilled their guts.
They just told us everything.
They confided in us.
It was mother confessed her.
It was sister.
It was...
you know, girlfriend, all rode in to one.
They didn't do that to me.
Going over, this was a 23-hour flight with two stops.
I had managed to miss my port call through not knowing
just how long it was going to take to get from San Francisco Airport out to Travis and how I had to get there and so on.
There was no direct bus, surprisingly.
And so I missed it by about 20 minutes.
And so I spent about two and a half days at Travis Airport Space waiting to go over.
And when I did, I was the only woman on the plane and the only officer on the plane.
Well, being the only officer didn't count because I was a nurse.
And nurses were not to command.
We were never to be in command situations, even if we were the only officer.
But I was really the senior person.
There were nine NCOs.
They were all young.
The oldest one was under 30.
I was 23.
And he had just made Sergeant First Class, and no experience as, you know, Sergeant First Class in any big situation.
And in the course of that flight, we were put in the front of the plane that was partitioned off from the back, and the front had about ten seats in it.
It would be like the first class section, except it was not first class.
We were just as packed as the guys in the back.
We were just separated.
And so I was put up there with them.
And during that trip, every single one of those guys sat with me sometime or other.
They just played musical chairs.
And I heard every guy's story.
Every single one.
And the senior NCO was real nervous about being senior and worried about just everything.
He was very open about it, talked a lot about his wife and so on.
Well, the tradition was, or the practice was, as much as possible, when you got to Hawaii, you got off and got a bottle.
if at all possible.
And he had talked to guys and, you know, somebody knew how to do this and still get back on the plane.
Now, we all got off the plane and had the opportunity to go into the bar.
But, you know, the deal was to get a bottle and bring it back on.
And so he told me how he planned to do this and so on.
And I was included in it, you know, so that when he did get on and he got back with just minutes to spare, it wasn't a matter of going into...
you know, the airport gift shop.
You had to get a cab and go into town or go along the strip, you know, several miles away.
And we were only on the ground for about two hours.
He got there just in the nick of time.
And then I hid the bottle behind me because, you know, would you do this?
Because the stewardess would never suspect you.
And so then we just, you know, passed little drinks around and nobody...
Nobody, I don't think, wanted to at that point.
It was just something they had to do.
They had to go through this ritual of securing the bottle.
But it was funny how they all just bounced around, you know.
But that got to be old hat after a while.
And, you know, we came to resent it, you know, at some point or another.
I caused a fight in an officer's club one night because of it.
I went in and had some sewing or mending, something to do, and didn't want to do it in my room.
I did not want to be alone.
I didn't want to interact with anybody, but I wanted people around, and that was all we had as a living room place to go.
And this character would not leave me alone.
He'd had too much, and he was kind of weaving a bit, and eventually somebody came over and stepped in, but
He was loud, and it almost came to fisticuffs between these two.
And how did the doctors treat you?
We were treated well.
They wanted people who could do their job around them.
They wanted well-trained nurses.
And if that's what you were, they treated you very well.
And if you weren't...
Then you were treated that way.
You were just kind of...
I had a young nurse on the medical ward who was very young and very immature.
And just kind of seemed to be in la-la land, you know.
And she did what she was told.
For the most part, she reported what she needed to report.
But she was just not grown up.
And that's the way she was treated.
How did you feel when you came home?
Well, I was suffering culture shock without really naming it.
I wanted to leave.
I was really eager to leave.
I got here and I wanted to go back.
I didn't want to stay.
There was nothing here for me.
I didn't really want to talk about what I'd been through.
I would have answered questions.
And for the most part, people didn't ask.
And I didn't want to bring them up.
I went to work in a civilian hospital in New Orleans.
And I didn't realize at the time, but New Orleans was really way
It was really in the dark ages as far as nursing was concerned.
The chief nurses were running around in starched uniforms.
I hadn't seen uniforms that starched even in college.
Only one of the nurses in the nursing service office had even a bachelor's degree.
Her bachelor's was in education.
So these were just diploma trained nurses, you know, senior of course, and very much concerned with keeping things the way they were.
They were just beginning to do team nursing.
It's what they called team nursing, but it was not team nursing, and that was really the being in thing at the time.
Team nursing was fun.
I was looking forward to doing that again, because we had not done it in the Army.
We weren't staffed on each ward enough to do it.
And there were, as I was being oriented at that hospital, three black women nurses were pointed out to me.
And they were all very recent graduates.
They were just, you know, that year's crop.
from a local black university.
Is it Dillard or is it Howard?
I don't know.
But there's a large black university in New Orleans.
And they were graduating with a degree, Bachelor of Science degree, nurses.
And this was the first time any of them had been hired by this hospital.
Boy, were they watching them.
And so far, they're turning out just fine.
But it was, you know, they didn't expect them to, and they didn't want them to.
I mean, that's where I really encountered racism.
You know, what was very blatant.
Coming home.
When I went to work there, I worked in a recovery room.
And a couple or three times I said something about, oh, you know the way we did this in Vietnam.
They were not interested.
You know, I would have thought, I would have been interested in that.
We had to...
We had a very peculiar way of giving, or I thought it was peculiar, way of giving packed red cells to patients.
We had no centrifuge, so there was no way of spinning down a unit of blood.
They would just set the unit out to settle.
And then you'd send your most sure-footed corpsman over to the lab to get it, and you'd very, very carefully hang it.
You know, you had to stick your tubing in and not jostle this.
We did have plastic bags.
It was plastic bags that the blood was in.
And then you had to be careful watching it.
I mean, you know, watch it carefully as it went in.
Make sure you got it or you stopped it when the red cells were in.
And, you know, it's not a problem.
Great story, but I mean, you know, it fits a battle situation.
And you'd think people would, you know, be polite at least to you as you told the story, and, you know, they weren't.
They didn't want to hear it.
We had to hold on to patients longer than we should have at times because of the...
medevac procedures.
The Air Force did the air back.
It was their planes, their personnel, their nurses and everything who carried patients out of country, well even up country, like to the in-country convalescent center at Cameron Bay.
So the Air Force wrote the rules and these were, you know, big airliners pressurized to like
you know, our passenger airplanes are.
And even pressurized at altitude, they are still pressurized only to about 6,000 feet.
You know, you get somebody who is anemic, has a heart condition or whatever, and take them up to Denver, and they can get into trouble.
That's 5,000 feet.
So the patients did have to be stable.
They had to have a certain red blood count before the Air Force would let them on the plane.
On the medical ward, we got a lot of patients who had hemolytic anemia.
And they were very depleted.
Well, most of the patients like that were Vietnamese or Thai.
There was only one airbag flight to Bangkok a week.
So if you didn't get your Thai patient on the plane on Monday, you had him until next Monday.
And again, it was a matter of, and these people, by the time they were ready for airbag home, were not feeling too bad.
They would have gotten up and left if they could have gotten away with it.
They hated our food.
They didn't understand our bathroom facilities.
They couldn't communicate with us.
I don't remember any word out of Thai that I learned, any Thai word that I learned.
I did learn, you know, a few Vietnamese words and phrases, but I don't remember any Thai.
And we came to, oh, we couldn't stand the Thai patients.
The other thing about the Thais was they would be visited by great numbers of their friends.
And always before coming in to visit a friend, they would stop at RPX and buy out the place.
What a greedy, selfish lot.
But anyway, a little thing like
not having enough red blood cells, you know, we'd keep one of those guys with us for another week.
So it was important to, you know, we would give them a transfusion the night before.
And again, you know, nobody was interested in that story.
So I soon learned not to talk about it.
And, uh,
And looking back, you know, I should have been talking about it.
I should have been talking about it to my family.
I should have somehow let them know that it was all right to ask me questions.
I remember at Christmas, you know, really, not at Christmas, but holidays as they came out.
New Year's certainly had been fun over there.
And, you know, I wasn't stepping into it.
any sort of a circle of friends back home that was going to party on New Year's.
It was just complete culture shock.
And I went, you know, back into civilian nursing, and that made it worse.
And the particular kind of civilian nursing, it was not.
The Army has a very high level of nursing.
I didn't appreciate that at the time until I got out, but it really does.
High educational standards, and...
You know, I was going to the Dark Ages, plus the prejudice.
And the other thing that had gone on just shortly before I came home, the whole Milo scandal broke.
And even though I had nothing to do with that, was not even in the area where the Americal Division operated, wasn't part of any of that, I was part of the Army.
